true.say: I just had a few questions, do you have a few minutes?
true.page: Another interview? I have a few minute to spare now, what are you interested in knowing?
true.say: What made you choose to write?
true.page: Well, that’s quite a question...
What makes the artist paint?
What makes the opera singer perform?
It is the best way I can express myself, my ideas.
I have always been tremendously interested in the written word.
true.say: Would you say that interest in a subject is fundamental to pursuing a career in that field?
true.page: Absolutely.
Yet, that isn’t the only thing that drives one’s success in a given field.
Aptitude, or the ability to perform well within a field is tremendously valuable.
Don’t let me lead you astray--it hasn’t always been as simple as putting pen to paper for me.
Russian, as beautiful of a language as any other, has its limitations.
I’m forced to explore the use of other words, words loaned from other languages if you would, to supplement my writing as needed.
true.say: So interests have to be tempered with aptitude?
true.page: Most certainly.
Yet, as with any career, these things must also be a priority.
You must always ask yourself, "how does this line of work mesh with the priorities in my life?"
You wouldn’t expect a good doctor to prioritize free time over seeing patients, now would you?
true.say: Thank you! I’ve learned a lot!
Your perfect job is at sweet spot between interests, aptitude and priorities.
